title.narrative: FAO 2019-2021 Early Warning Tools for Resilience Building in IGAD Region
FAO 2019-2021 Early Warning Tools for Resilience Building in IGAD Region

description.narrative:
Insatsens övergripande syfte är att bidra till att rädda liv genom säkrade försörjningmöjligheter, förebygga människors lidande (utan att öka försörjningsbördan för såväl män som kvinnor) och att underlätta för ett humanitärt evidens baserat tidigt varningssystem och därmed en långsiktig hållbar utveckling i Östafrika.
Insatsens mål: 1. Motverka effekterna av naturkatastrofer för pastoralister och agro-pastoralister (män och kvinnor) genom att använda tidiga varningssystem på ett effektivt sätt och att realiteter, behov, mäns och kvinnors prioriteringar i regionen ingår i dessa system. 2. Identifiera och harmonisera tidiga varningssystem så att dessa når ut effektivt i handlingsprogram och förebyggande katastrofplaner.
FAO:s Resilience Team, Östafrika, ansvarar för insatsen och samarbetar med AgriTechTalk International, Texas A&M University, IGAD och dess medlemsstater.
Insatsen fokuserar på Kenya, Somalia och Uganda.
Insatsens totala kostnad är 35 MSEK och ska genomföras under en två-års period (från december 2019 till november 2021)

The overall purpose of this project is to contribute to saving lives through saving livelihoods, alleviating human suffering (without adding burden to either men or women) and paving the way for evidence-based humanitarian early and long-term development actions in the East Africa region.
The project has the following expected outcomes: 1. Mitigating impacts of natural shocks to pastoral and agro-pastoral men and women through the deployment of early warning tools that take into account the realities, needs, priorities of women and men in the region. 2. Harmonized early warning systems identified to inform effective early action programs
The project will be implemented by FAO’s Resilience Team for Eastern Africa in collaboration with AgriTechTalk International, Texas A&M University, the Intergovernmental Authority on Development and its member countries. Focus countries of the project will be Kenya, Somalia, and Uganda. The total cost the project is SEK 35 000 000 and will be implemented over a period of two years (Dec 2019 – Nov 2021)

Overall Impact: To contribute to saving lives through saving livelihoods, alleviating human suffering (without adding burden to either men or women) and paving the way for evidence-based humanitarian early and long term development actions in the East Africa region The project has the following expected outcomes: Outcome 1: Mitigating impacts of natural shocks to pastoral and agro-pastoral men and women through the deployment of early warning tools that take into account the realities, needs, priorities of women and men in the region. Outcome 2: Harmonized early warning systems identified to inform effective early action programmes

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.

description.narrative: This Conclusion on Performance (CoP) covers the first year of implementation of the FAO Early Warning Tools for Increased Resilience of Livelihoods in IGAD Region during the period January - December 2020. The project is planned to be implemented over a period of two years. During the first year of implementation which also coincided with the COVID-19 pandemic, FAO, along with ICPALD (IGAD Center for Pastoral Areas and Livestock Development) for outcome 1 and Tufts University (for outcome 2) has made progress towards achieving the goal of the project. However, face to face meetings and field visits that were planned, especially under outcome 1 have been seriously affected by restrictions on travel and meetings due to COVID-19. Overall, FAO's achievements are satisfactory given the circumstances the project was implemented in. It was possible to raise awareness, to engage relevant ministries, designate focal persons, conduct trainings, collect data through questionnaires, produce templates and conduct reviews of early warning and early action practices in the region. Summary of achievements as per FAO's report are presented below. Outcome 1: Mitigating impacts of natural shocks to pastoral and agro-pastoral men and women through the deployment of early warning tools that take into account the realities, needs, priorities of women and men in the region. National focal points were appointed in Kenya, Somalia and Uganda and National advisory and thematic technical task forces were established in these countries. Feedback on scoping questionnaires to obtain qualitative data was received from Somalia and Uganda, with the latter having good data for the three pillars. For the former, FAO-Somalia is assisting to get data from Food Security and Nutrition Analysis Unit for Somalia (FSNAU) and Somalia and Water and Land Information Management (SWALIM). Animal and crop resource tools were developed and used to collect data from the 24 non-Arid and Semi Arid Lands (ASAL) counties in Kenya. Animal feed requirements as Dry Matter (DM), Metoblizable Energy (ME) and Crude Protein (CP) are 100% complete. All participating countries are now well aware of the importance of feed assessments, feed balance, feed security assessment and early warning system for feed availability; as well as the approaches to be used and data requirements for these assessments. Overall, the project implementation has been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and the restrictive measures implemented by the countries targeted by the activity. However, during the reporting period, the programme still managed to engage with the governments of all the targeted countries. While in Uganda there were some delays in engagement due to government internal procedures, in the other three countries engagement has been successful. Furthermore, Somalia have already established the National Advisory Committees and the National Technical Committees for the three pillars and have provided the information required for the livestock sector data mapping. The implementation of virtual meetings has been instrumental in achieving the results mentioned above, as both the awareness and scoping mission activities were initially planned to be implemented through physical missions to the target areas. However, key activities planned under this outcome heavily depended on face to face trainings and meetings including support to field data collection, analysis and reporting. Hence the need to revise the work plan and budget to complete these activities and achieve the required outputs. Outcome 2: Harmonized early warning systems identified to inform effective early action programmes A team of early warning experts conducted 84 interviews with 125 individuals between July and November 2020 and reviewed early warning systems in all countries in the IGAD region, as well as 17 predictive food security models. A draft report outlining key findings from this study, as well as recommendations for FAO and IGAD, was written and submitted to FAO after the end of the reporting period in early February 2020 and is currently under review.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
